properties.details: Sherrard was shot once in the chest in a hotel parking lot and died at Harborview Medical Center. Jacob Thiel, now 23, was found hiding nearby. He was charged with second-degree murder for allegedly shooting Sherrard because he believed Sherrard had stolen Thiel’s cellphone and other electronics.

Co-workers Garcia and Tapia were having drinks at the Taradise Café, a bar patronized by Merle “Chucky” Buchanan. When Tapia was kicked out for being intoxicated, he struck up a conversation with Buchanan outside while Garcia waited nearby. After about 15 minutes, surveillance footage showed Buchanan shooting Tapia in the face and Garcia in the head before driving away. Buchanan, now 27, turned himself in to police two months later and was charged with two counts of second-degree murder.

A woman who lives near the building where Benegas lived called 911 after finding human remains in a suitcase. The medical examiner determined Benegas died from multiple stab wounds and decapitation. Tukwila police arrested Benegas’ cousin, Rosalio Ramos Ramos, now 38. Ramos, who has been charged with second-degree murder, was in the country illegally and had been previously deported to Honduras four times.

Ayers was tortured, raped and stabbed by a man who, choosing at random, walked into her Lake City house through her unlocked back door. Her killer set her body on fire in an effort to destroy DNA evidence. Seattle police arrested Michael Giordano, now 24, in Pioneer Square. He was charged with aggravated first-degree murder.

Hernandez’s 9-year-old daughter called 911 on Dec. 14, 2017, and reported that her brother, Heriberto Alcantar Hernandez, was strangling and punching their mother. Hernandez, found on the ground outside the house, was airlifted to Harborview Medical Center, where doctors found the blade of a 5-inch knife in her skull. Alcantar, now 21, was arrested at a bus stop a mile from the family home with blood on his hands and clothing. He was initially charged with first-degree assault domestic violence but the charge was amended to second-degree murder domestic violence after his mother was taken off life support. Court records indicate Alcantar has been diagnosed with a serious mental illness and it appears unlikely he will be found competent to stand trial.

Pigford was stabbed multiple times in a Rainier Beach parking lot and died a short time later at Harborview Medical Center. Police interviewed a 34-year-old woman, who returned to the scene and said she had been injured in an altercation with Pigford. King County prosecutors declined to file criminal charges after determining the woman killed Pigford in self-defense.

In an attempted marijuana rip-off, Phung, who was in his car, was shot in the back in the parking lot at Renton High School and crashed his vehicle outside a church. Though police have not arrested the suspected shooter, two alleged accomplices were arrested. Dyonte Jackson, 20, was charged with first-degree murder. A then-17-year-old was initially charged as an adult with first-degree murder, but court records show he pleaded guilty to first-degree robbery in juvenile court and the murder charge was dismissed. In September, he was sentenced to 52 weeks

Tyson was shot after a fight broke out near a Chevron gas station where an open-air drug market is known to operate. A 17-year-old boy was wounded by gunfire and another 17-year-old was struck by a car as he ran away. There have been no arrests in connection with Tyson’s death, which may have been gang related.

Lewis was shot in the chest inside Studio Seven, a heavy-metal nightclub and hard-rock venue in Seattle’s Sodo neighborhood. Police have not identified the person who killed him. As a result of the shooting and several earlier incidents, the Washington State Liquor and Cannabis Board revoked the club’s liquor license and Studio Seven was permanently closed.
A woman heard gunshots and found Matthews, a Kent father of six, dead in her driveway. Though the woman knew Matthews, she wasn’t expecting him at her house. No arrests have been made.

Esparza and his mother were seated at a picnic table near a taco truck in South Park when they were swarmed by a group of people on Feb. 7. Esparza tried to run away and was shot four times. He later died at Harborview Medical Center. In July, Juan Macias, now 27, was arrested and charged with first-degree murder and first-degree unlawful possession of a firearm in what was investigated as a gang-related shooting. Macias apparently believed that Esparza had stolen from him on New Year’s Day but court records don’t indicate what was allegedly taken.

Rodriguez was found dead, inside a vehicle, from a gunshot wound to the head. His death was initially investigated as a suicide before the King County Medical Examiner’s Office ruled it a homicide. There have been no arrests.

Responding to a report of a car prowler in Ravenna, Seattle police ended up pursuing a suspect, who exchanged gunfire with them. Police then received a report that someone had broken into a house eight blocks from the original scene and had stolen a car at gunpoint. The suspect, later identified as Seavers, crashed the car and was shot several times inside the vehicle as officers tried to take him into custody. A police video showed Seavers ignoring officers’ commands and searching the back seat and rear floorboard with his hand. Police later found a gun inside the vehicle.

On March 8, someone summoned medical aid for the baby boy, who was taken to Seattle Children’s hospital. The following day, doctors contacted police and reported that Loki was the victim of child abuse. At the time of his death from brain injury, he had multiple rib fractures in various stages of healing. No one was arrested because police were unable to determine who was responsible for his fatal injuries.

A friend went to Byrnes’ Wallingford home and found her dead. Byrnes’ throat had been slashed and she had been stabbed 60 to 70 times. In late April, prosecutors charged Byrnes’ roommate, Ian Flaherty, with first-degree murder. Byrnes’ family told police she had been attempting to evict Flaherty, now 26, because he wasn’t paying his share of expenses.

Price was beaten on Feb. 10, 2017 and the attack left him paralyzed and in a mostly-comatose state. A relative transferred Price to a rehabilitation center in Arizona, where he died from his injuries. Police are investigating his death as a homicide but have made no arrests.

Duncan, who was homeless, was shot in the face on a Burien street and died two days later. The shooting was witnessed by a female motorist and was captured by video-surveillance cameras at a nearby business. On March 20, detectives spotted a man at the Burien Transit Center who appeared to be wearing the same clothes as the gunman seen in the video. Towle Leichliter, 46, was detained; detectives found a .40-caliber handgun in his backpack that was matched to a shell casing found at the shooting scene. The motive for the shooting is unknown. Leichliter was arrested and charged with second-degree murder.

Cortez and Juarez were hanging out with a large group of teens at the Alturas @ Burien apartment complex when they apparently got into an argument with a member of a rival gang. Both were shot multiple times. No arrests have been made. Cortez and Juarez are presumed victims of an ongoing war between rival Hispanic street gangs in South King County.

Scotland was strangled and then after her death was stabbed to make it appear part of a robbery. Aterraka Scotland, now 27, was arrested at a Redmond bus stop on April 4 and has been charged with second-degree murder domestic violence. According to prosecutors, Aterraka Scotland killed her wife after finding out she was having an affair.

Several people called 911 to report hearing gunshots and Seattle police found McKoy, a rapper who went by the moniker “Juice The God,” lying in the street with a gunshot wound to the head. No arrests have been made.

Witnesses at a hit-and-run told police a man and woman had fled their crashed vehicle into a residential neighborhood and attempted to steal a car. Officers arrested the woman, but the man broke into an unoccupied house and armed himself with a gun he found inside. After a nine-hour standoff, a SWAT team entered the house and found Nelson hiding in the crawl space. He fired at officers twice, then exchanged gunfire with a 39-year-old Federal Way police officer, who shot Nelson several times.

On April 13, Seattle police responded to a report of an unresponsive man inside a camper near the Ballard Bridge. Officers initially assumed Matteson had died of natural causes. During an autopsy, investigators discovered Matteson had been shot in the chest, triggering a homicide investigation. No arrests have been made.

Balesh got into a fight with a male relative at his father’s apartment and was stabbed to death. His relative, now 37, was arrested on investigation of homicide but was released from jail on April 19 and has not been criminally charged. According to prosecutors, evidence in the case suggests the relative killed Balesh in self-defense.

Baker, the older brother of Bishard “Budda” Baker, a former UW Husky football player who now plays in the NFL for the Arizona Cardinals, died on a Ballard street from a gunshot wound to the chest. Police say video-surveillance footage shows Robert Baker inside the Cedar Room, where he and Christopher Gates appeared to recognize each other. Gates is accused of following Baker from the club and shooting him. Gates, now 26, was charged with first-degree murder.

A wild shootout in the parking lot shared by the Skyway Veterans of Foreign Wars post and Tha Family Motorcycle Club ended with at least four people shot. Cabine died in the parking lot of a nearby McDonald’s restaurant. Justice was driven in a private vehicle to Valley Medical Center, where he died. Two others were shot but survived. No arrests have been made.

Cervantes Villanueva was among a group of young men who were hanging out at a female friend’s house until her mother told them to leave. He was waiting for a ride and sat in the front seat of a dilapidated BMW with a 14-year-old boy. The 14-year-old was taking selfies of himself with a 9 mm handgun when the weapon discharged, hitting Cervantes Villanueva. The shooter fled to Texas but was arrested July 8 in a traffic stop as he and his sister were on their way to their mother’s house in Kent. The shooter, who has since turned 15, was charged in juvenile court with first-degree manslaughter and first-degree unlawful possession of a firearm. He pleaded guilty in January and was sentenced to 52 to 65 weeks.
Marr was shot multiple times in the parking lot at West Seattle Stadium and was declared dead at Harborview Medical Center. No arrests have been made.

During a gathering at a friend’s house, a 21-year-old man was mishandling his gun when it accidentally discharged. A round hit Glover in the neck and he died at the scene. The shooting was ruled accidental and no one was charged.

Manuel Ramirez Nava, who was 16 at the time, allegedly stole a .38-caliber handgun from his neighbor and was playing around with the weapon at a birthday party. Two witnesses reported seeing Ramirez cock the gun, which went off. A bullet struck Bingham in the head and he died at the scene. Ramirez was charged as an adult with first-degree manslaughter and second-degree unlawful possession of a firearm.

Dela Cruz and a group of friends were “ghost hunting” in Seattle’s Martha Washington Park when a group of suspected gang members pulled up in a car. The group in the car opened fire and Dela Cruz was shot three times. Dela Cruz, who had planned to join the Marines, was weeks from graduating from Franklin High School when he was killed. No arrests have been made.

Pecina was stabbed in the neck by another man in what police say was a targeted attack near Luna Park on the West Seattle waterfront. There have been no arrests. In January, Seattle police used evidence from Pecina’s killing to produce the department’s first video showcasing evidence from a homicide investigation and announced that detectives have the unidentified killer’s DNA.
Lafferty was shot in the chest, apparently by someone he knew following a fight. The shooter fled before police arrived. No one has been arrested.

Four Redmond police officers fired 13 rounds at Castellano at a gas station in Kirkland’s Kingsgate neighborhood, striking him at least four times. Castellano, who had a pending felony drug charge, was being investigated for eluding a police vehicle and nine counts of identity theft, according to a police spokeswoman. The police investigation into the shooting is still underway.

Arancio, a clerk at the America’s Best Value Airport Inn, was shot in the chest during a robbery in which $150 was taken. Daye’vion Royalston, 26, was arrested in Dayton, Ohio, five days later and was charged with first-degree murder and first-degree unlawful possession of a firearm.

Barreto was days from graduating from Mount Rainier High School when police say her boyfriend lured her to Salt Air Vista Park and shot her in the head. Giovanni “Gio” Herrin, now 20, was arrested June 19 and is charged with first-degree murder domestic violence and first-degree unlawful possession of a firearm. In July, he escaped from Harborview Medical Center after faking a medical emergency. Herrin was shot in the shoulder by a jail officer a half-mile away and was taken back into custody.

Gutierrez, shot eight times, was found in the driver’s seat of his car in Shoreline. Nine hours later, Seattle police arrested a then-17-year-old, Luis Campuzano, for unlawful possession of a firearm. Police found a 9 mm handgun in Campuzano’s vehicle that was later matched to shell casings found at the homicide scene. Sheriff’s deputies obtained video footage that showed Campuzano getting into Gutierrez’s car and leaving a short time later with a backpack. The apparent motive for the killing was the alleged robbery of cocaine and cash. Campuzano, now 18, was charged as an adult with first-degree murder and unlawful possession of a firearm.
Seattle police responded to a report of a stabbing in Pioneer Square and found Roberts dead from a stab wound to the chest. There have been no arrests.

Dasalla and her boyfriend, Kenneth Thomas, were arguing in their bedroom when Dasalla texted her son, telling him he needed to leave the house. As the son left, he heard gunshots and called 911. Officers found Dasalla, dead from a gunshot wound to the neck, on the floor of her bedroom. Thomas, 48, was arrested and is charged with second-degree murder domestic violence.

Morales and a 32-year-old man were shot following a hip-hop concert at a music venue in Sodo. Police officers, who were already patrolling the area as a large crowd was leaving the concert, heard gunshots and discovered the victims. Morales died a short time later at Harborview Medical Center. The second victim was treated for non-life-threatening injuries. No arrests have been made.

When Landers and her husband didn’t show up at a Fourth of July party, a friend went to their house and called 911 after discovering Landers’ body. She died from multiple gunshot wounds. The body of her husband, Paul Landers, 51, was also inside the home. His death, from a handgun wound to the head, was ruled a suicide. Police are still awaiting lab results but the deaths were investigated as a murder-suicide.

Anderson and another friend were hanging out in the bedroom of Loren Mertes, 20, who was playing with a loaded shotgun. Mertes, who later claimed he didn’t know the gun was loaded, chambered a shell and pulled the trigger, striking Anderson in the chest. Mertes was charged with first-degree manslaughter.

Brown and another teenage friend were hanging out at the home of John Mugo, who was also 17 at the time. All three had guns and took a variety of photos of themselves with the weapons. Prosecutors say Mugo was playing around with his gun and shot Brown once in the head, then attempted to make it appear that Brown had shot himself. Mugo was charged as an adult with first-degree manslaughter and first-degree unlawful possession of a firearm.

Chikh and a male friend had gone for dinner and were leaving a shopping plaza when Chikh’s husband, Ignacio Cisneros, used his vehicle to block Chikh’s vehicle. He got out of his car and angrily confronted Chikh. Cisneros then returned to his vehicle, got a handgun and shot Chikh and her friend as they sat inside her Cadillac Escalade. Cisneros turned himself in to police five days later. He was charged with premeditated first-degree murder domestic violence and attempted first-degree murder.

Officers responded to a 911 report of a man down in the street and found Abay dead from numerous stab wounds. A few weeks after the homicide, police released video-surveillance footage of two men and two women associated with the stabbing in an effort to identify them. No arrests have been made.

Kent police responded to a report of gunshots outside a restaurant and witnesses pointed to a red pickup that drove from the scene without its headlights on. The driver, Emiliano Garcia, then 16, led police on a high-speed chase. Officer Mark Williams pursued the pickup and accidentally struck and killed Officer Moreno, who had just placed spike strips across the roadway. Garcia crashed the pickup a mile east; he and one of his passengers fled. The second passenger was arrested and charged in juvenile court with unlawfully possessing a gun and cocaine. The passenger who fled with Garcia was later charged with unlawful possession of a firearm. Garcia, who was arrested at his Kent residence later that day, was charged as an adult with second-degree murder. He remains jailed in lieu of $1 million bail.

A motel employee found Wu’s body in her room and called police. Based on video-surveillance footage, detectives identified Pvt. 2nd Class Krishna Mahadevan-Prasad, 20, of Woodridge, New Jersey, as a suspect. The Army Ranger had transferred to Joint Base Lewis-McCord two weeks earlier. Early the next day, Mahadevan-Prasad – who was armed with a shotgun and an assault-style rifle – fired at parked vehicles waiting for the Hood Canal Bridge to open. He then shot and killed himself.

King County sheriff’s Deputy Leland Adams was looking for parking violators in the garage at Kent Station. He came across a suspicious vehicle and was contacting two men when he was told over his police radio that the car had been reported stolen. Adams tried to arrest the driver, later identified as Hernandez. Hernandez armed himself with an AR-15 rifle and fought with the deputy. Adams fired a single shot, striking Hernandez in the chest. He died a short time later at Harborview Medical Center.

Witnesses told police they saw some kind of disturbance, then saw a car quickly driven off. They found a man’s body on the ground and called police. The victim, Kotthoff, died from a gunshot wound to the head. Police identified two men, who were 43 and 37 at the time, as being involved in Kotthoff’s death. Prosecutors declined to file criminal charges after determining the men acted in self-defense.

Someone called 911 to report that a man and a woman had been shot. Guerrero died at the scene and the female victim, who was shot in the leg, was treated at Harborview Medical Center. No arrests have been made but police do not think the shooting was random.

Fehlen and other passengers aboard a Metro bus were angry at a teenage rider who repeatedly pulled the stop cord. When Fehlen indicated he was getting off the bus, the teen left the bus before him. The teenager, later identified as 16-year-old Loyan Ahmed, fired at Fehlen, hitting him four times before running away. Police found Fehlen on the sidewalk next to the bus; he died a short time later at Harborview Medical Center. Police identified Ahmed through surveillance footage and he was arrested on Aug. 15. He was charged as an adult with second-degree murder and second-degree unlawful possession of a firearm.

On Aug. 14, someone called 911 and reported a body covered in a bloody blanket under Interstate 5. Police went to what is believed to have been a single-person homeless encampment and found Hall dead of a head injury. There have been no arrests.

Devereaux, who was about to begin his freshman year at Bothell High School, was spending the summer at the home of his friend, Jonathan Anderson. Anderson, 16, was allegedly playing around with a 9 mm handgun when he pulled the trigger and shot Devereaux in the face. Devereaux died at Harborview Medical Center. Police, who believe the 9 mm was stolen, later found two other guns – also believed to be stolen – in Anderson’s bedroom. Anderson was charged as an adult with first-degree manslaughter and second-degree unlawful possession of a firearm.

Members of the King County sheriff’s SWAT team served a warrant on Peppan’s residence to search for drugs and guns. Deputies George Alvarez, Jesse Herrera and Steve Shalloway confronted Peppan in a bedroom and he grabbed a handgun. According to the sheriff’s office, Peppan ignored commands to drop the weapon and moved the gun toward the deputies, who fired and shot him.

After an evening hanging out, Daniels invited Esmond Earl Holmes and a woman back to his tent to sleep. Holmes, 56, left after arguing with Daniels. Hours later, Holmes returned and demanded Daniels’ money and possessions. Daniels threw a couple dollar bills at Holmes, who apparently was angry he didn’t get more cash and allegedly stabbed Daniels in the left leg. Daniels died at the scene from blood loss. Holmes was arrested six days later after his wife called 911 to report an assault and officers recognized Holmes’ name from the earlier homicide investigation. Holmes was charged with first-degree murder.

After relatives were unable to reach Leenawarat for a couple days, the building manager of The Malloy apartments was asked to check on her on Sept. 4. The manager summoned police, who found Leenawarat dead from several stab wounds. The body of her roommate, 32-year-old Thiti-on Chotechuangsab, was also found in the apartment. Investigators determined Leenawarat was killed by Chotechuangsab, who died from a self-inflicted stab wound to the chest. Both women were Thai nationals and master’s students at the University of Washington’s law school.

Police responded to reports of gunshots and found a possible shooting scene, where witnesses reported seeing a green sedan driven away from the area. Officers also were sent to Harborview Medical Center, where a gunshot victim, later identified as Bennett, had been dropped off. He died at the hospital from a gunshot wound to the abdomen. There have been no arrests.

Reyes, the office manager at a chiropractor’s office, was seated at the front counter when a stray bullet came through the window and struck her in the chest. Two 17-year-olds – Adnel Kenjar, the suspected gunman who has since turned 18, and Orlando Calderon Garcia, the alleged driver of an SUV used in the drive-by shooting – were each charged as adults with second-degree murder and second-degree unlawful possession of a firearm. Kenjar and Calderon are members of one gang and their alleged target was a 39-year-old member of a rival gang.

Riley was driving south on Rainier Avenue South when someone in a black or dark-colored sedan opened fire on her vehicle. Riley’s car veered across the center line, sideswiped one car and crashed into another before coming to rest on the sidewalk. Officers found Riley dead from a gunshot wound to the head. There have been no arrests.

Police responded to several disturbances at a homeless encampment and while there, officers received a 911 call about a man bleeding on the ground nearby. Yelle, who was homeless, died at Harborview Medical Center from a stab wound to the chest. No arrests have been made.

A contractor went to pick up equipment he’d left at Morphis’ seven-acre property and called 911 after finding Morphis’ body wrapped in a tarp inside a shed. Morphis had been bludgeoned to death and his throat was slit. A week later, Jeremy Shaw, 39, of Tacoma, was arrested and charged with first-degree murder for allegedly killing Morphis, a stranger, so he could take possession of the older man’s three-bedroom rambler. Shaw and his wife, Lorena Shaw, were together charged with residential burglary, first-degree conspiracy to commit theft, and second-degree arson for allegedly stealing and torching Morphis’ car. Lorena Shaw, 37, was also charged with felony rendering criminal assistance.
After someone reported hearing gunshots in Belltown, police found Zerahaimanot on the ground. He died at the scene from multiple gunshot wounds. There have been no arrests.

Rea, who owned a landscaping business, died in his garage from a gunshot wound to the torso. Rigoberto Rodriguez Macedo, a 29-year-old who had worked for Rea, was charged with second-degree murder and first-degree unlawful possession of a firearm. Rodriguez was allegedly angry over money he believed Rea owed him. Rodriguez attempted to flee to Mexico after the killing but was arrested Oct. 10 at a bus terminal in Huntington Park, Calif.
After a passer-by called 911 to report hearing gunshots, officers found Haywood and Walker inside a parked car, both dead from numerous gunshot wounds. No arrests have been made.

Prosecutors say John Davis, 55, became fixated on Alberto, a homeless man Davis believed was responsible for breaking a window at Davis’ apartment months earlier. Davis spotted Alberto walking on the street and stopped his car to confront him. Alberto went to the driver’s side window, then walked to the rear of the car and began to walk away, but then turned back and approached the front passenger window of Davis’ car. He was immediately shot and died from a gunshot wound to the chest. Davis was charged with second-degree murder.

Carter was shot twice with a 9 mm handgun and died in the parking lot of a shopping complex. Nine days later, police arrested Yourhighness Bolar, now 23, after a tipster recognized Bolar and his vehicle from media accounts and provided his name to investigators. It’s unclear whether Carter knew Bolar and the motive for the shooting is unknown. Bolar was charged with second-degree murder and first-degree unlawful possession of a firearm.

Garcia and David Lee Morris, 29, were in an on-again, off-again relationship and together had a 5-year-old son. The family was at a pizza place at the Seattle Center Armory when Morris is accused of repeatedly stabbing Garcia in the neck in front of their son and horrified witnesses. A witness held Morris at gunpoint until police arrived. Morris was charged with first-degree murder domestic violence.
Williams, who was homeless, was found dead from a head injury. No arrests have been made.

Henrickson, who police say had a history of assaulting family members, was reportedly attacking his mother when his grandfather shot him several times. After the shooting, the grandfather went outside to meet responding officers. He was not arrested. Prosecutors have not made a formal disposition in the case but it appears the grandfather killed Henrickson to defend his daughter and himself.

Grendahl lived in an apartment and Tejuan Thomas, now 42, operated his tattoo studio in the building’s basement. On Nov. 7, Grendahl went to buy sodas from a basement vending machine and was hit on the head from behind, allegedly by Thomas, who told police he thought Grendahl was attempting to break into the machine. Grendahl declined to go to the hospital but hours later, he underwent emergency surgery. He never regained consciousness and died from a head injury. Thomas was charged with second-degree murder.

Villa Senor died from several gunshot wounds during a home-invasion robbery but before he died, he managed to return fire, wounding at least one of the intruders. Blood at the scene was matched to DNA belonging to Mical Roberts, 24, of Lynnwood. Prosecutors charged Roberts with first-degree murder in December. He was arrested in Tacoma on March 1.

Loto, a graduate of Highline High School in Burien, played football at College of San Mateo in California. Home for the holidays, Loto played in a pickup game of football on Thanksgiving Day on the Mount Rainier High School campus. There was a fight during the game, and one of the combatants left but returned a short time later with two family members. The man who was involved in the fight allegedly gave a .40-caliber handgun to 25-year-old William Holly, who is accused of firing 11 shots into a large group of people, striking Loto, who had not been involved in the fight. Prosecutors charged Holly with first-degree murder on Feb. 15 and he was arrested in Minnesota on Feb. 27.

Police were summoned to a house where a woman, Tam, had been shot outside. Officers entered the house and discovered an illegal marijuana grow operation as well as signs that someone had tried to break in. No one has been arrested.

Sampson and a male relative got into a fistfight inside a Skyway residence early on Nov. 23 and a female family member called 911. When deputies arrived, they spoke with Sampson, who was shirtless and covered in blood. As Sampson talked to deputies, swelling to his head worsened and he was taken to Harborview Medical Center in critical condition. He died two days later from head injuries. The male relative was initially booked into jail on investigation of assault but was released. Prosecutors are reviewing the case but no charges have been filed.

After bumping into Cristian Magana Arevalo earlier in the day, Hobbs agreed to meet Magana to settle a dispute with a fistfight. They met in the parking lot of an apartment complex, where Magana and a companion allegedly attacked Hobbs and chased him around a carport. Magana, 21, is accused of shooting Hobbs, who fell to the ground. Magana allegedly stood over him and fired five more times from close range. Police were able to identify Magana from video-surveillance footage and he was arrested on Dec. 7 in Bellevue. Magana was charged with first-degree murder.

A patrol officer heard gunshots early on Dec. 2 but couldn’t find evidence of a shooting. Two days later, a lawn-maintenance worker found Dahir’s body in the backyard of a house and called 911. Detectives found a cellphone next to Dahir’s body and when the phone was searched, they found photos and videos of Deon Robinson, a 34-year-old Seattle man. Detectives obtained a variety of video-surveillance footage which showed Robinson chasing Dahir, apparently to get his phone back. The footage included muzzle flashes consistent with gunfire. Robinson was arrested Dec. 17 and was charged with second-degree murder.

Based on witnesses and video-surveillance footage, police say Robert Fleeks chased George west on Yesler Way until they got outside a hotel. Fleeks, 19, allegedly kicked George in the face, then shot him in the abdomen. Fleeks then picked up George’s belongings, including cash and drugs, and ran from the scene as officers arrived. Fleeks – who was living in a tent under the West Seattle bridge at the time of the shooting – was arrested a short distance away and charged with second-degree murder and second-degree unlawful possession of a firearm.

Banos and a female friend pulled into the parking lot of an apartment building. Banos and another man were involved in an ongoing dispute and got into a heated argument. The other man shot Banos several times. The shooter fled before police arrived. The shooting remains under investigation.

Natalie and her younger brother lived with their father after their parents split up in 2015. Police say her mother, Svetlana Laurel, 52, showed up at the family home while Natalie and her father were away. Laurel is accused of restraining her 12-year-old son with zip ties. When her ex-husband and daughter returned, she allegedly used a stun gun on her ex-husband and bound him with zip ties. Natalie called 911 from her upstairs bedroom and was confronted by her mother, who is accused of first using zip ties to restrain Natalie and then shooting her between the eyes. Laurel is also accused of attempting to shoot her ex-husband, who police say took the gun away from her just as officers arrived. Laurel was charged with aggravated first-degree murder, attempted first-degree murder, first-degree kidnapping and unlawful imprisonment.

Sheriff’s deputies responded to a report of a shooting and inside a house found Sines dead from shotgun wounds. They removed several people, including a baby, from the residence. Reginald Lindsay III refused to come out and was involved in a three-hour standoff with a sheriff’s SWAT team. Officers sent a robot equipped with cameras into the house and saw Lindsay’s body on a bed, next to a shotgun. Lindsay, 32, died of a self-inflicted shotgun wound to the head. The deaths were ruled a murder-suicide.

A Seattle police officer pulled a car over for a traffic stop and the driver, later identified as Faletogo, jumped from the vehicle and ran across four lanes of traffic. Several officers ran after him. During a struggle with officers, Faletogo was shot in the head and died at the scene. Police say it appears Faletogo ignored officers’ commands and was reaching for a handgun when he was shot. His family has challenged the police account of the shooting.
